title: Yerin Ha on playing a leading role in Bridgerton | ABC NEWS
description: Korean-Australian actor Yerin Ha plays the leading role in the fourth season of Bridgerton.   We spoke to her on the AACTAs red carpet and asked how she thinks the Australian film and TV industry can do better when it comes to representation.   Reporting by Madeline Muir, ABC News Social Media Team.   ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Trump lifts tariffs to 15 pc after Supreme Court ruling | ABC NEWS
description: US President Donald Trump has hiked base tariffs on imports into his country to 15 per cent after the US Supreme Court struck down his Liberation Day import tax regime and deemed his use of emergency powers unlawful.  The White House is using powers vested by Section 122 to impose the new tariffs, which can only be extended with congressional approval after 150 days in effect.  Journalist Jay Newtown-Small says importers are facing ‘legal limbo’ as Trump’s slim majority in congress will face great difficulty in securing approval. title: Trump’s plan-B tariffs spark mass confusion among global exporters | ABC NEWS
description: US President Donald Trump’s decision to raise global tariffs to 15 per cent has sparked widespread confusion worldwide after the US Supreme Court rejected his Liberation Day import taxes.  The Trump administration is using the Trade Act of 1974’s Section 122 powers, which have never been invoked by a US president.  American consumers and international exporters are scrambling to find out whether they must abide by this new trade policy, as German Chancellor Friedrich Merz described the situation as the ‘poison of uncertainty’. title: What does the future hold for Punch the monkey? | ABC NEWS
description: A Japanese macaque named Punch has become widely known after videos showed him seeking comfort from an orangutan toy at Ichikawa City Zoo. The monkey was abandoned by his mother. Netizens around the world have expressed sympathy for the young primate at the Ichikawa City Zoo as the hashtag #HangInTherePunch gained vast traction.  Animal behaviour expert Carla Litchfield says Punch could be seen as a ‘messed-up, weird little guy’ if he cannot reintegrate into his troop. title: Does X’s algorithm make you more conservative? | ABC NEWS
description: A new study has found that using X’s personalised feed can push political views further to the right. Researchers observed a shift in political stance among people who moved from a chronological to an algorithmic feed. Philine Widmer from the Paris School of Economics says participants became more sceptical of criminal investigations into Donald Trump and the Ukrainian war effort after several weeks on the algorithmic feed. title: UK passport changes leave Australian dual citizens scrambling | ABC NEWS
description: Australians with British or Irish citizenship will need a valid British or Irish passport, or a certificate of entitlement to enter, to travel to the UK from February 25. The UK Home Office announced the rules last year, but many people only learned about the change through recent news reports. Travel industry leaders have asked the UK government to delay the new rules, warning that Australians could miss long-planned trips. title: How construction corruption is affecting housing affordability | Alan Kohler | ABC NEWS
description: Australia's housing crisis is often blamed on more people wanting homes than there are available. Fewer homes have been built because conflicts between unions and builders have slowed construction. The ABC's Alan Kohler looks at how corruption scandals, such as claims against the CFMEU, have affected the cost of buying a home. title: Minister reveals process has started to ban Islamist group Hizb ut-Tahrir under hate laws | ABC NEWS
description: Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke told the ABC's Insiders he had been advised by ASIO that Islamist group Hizb ut-Tahrir met the threshold to be listed under the new legal regime, which was established after the Bondi attack to capture those deemed to spread hate but not captured by existing laws.  Hizb ut-Tahrir was one of two groups the government had named as its main targets. The other, neo-Nazi group the National Socialist Network, disbanded in January.  Mr Burke said the next stage was a departmental briefing to satisfy him that the group increased the risk of hate-motivated violence, after which the opposition leader would be briefed and the attorney-general could sign off on a ban. title: Importers looking for refunds as Trump raises tariffs higher | ABC NEWS
description: The Australian government is expected to press Trump officials over the President's latest tariff tirade when the Trade Minister visits California.  After the US Supreme Court struck down Donald Trump's so-called Liberation Day tariffs, he signed off on a 10 per cent global duty, which he's now bumped up to 15 percent.  But importers are now asking how they can get their taxes refunded. title: Call for federal First Nations treaty to follow Victoria's lead | ABC NEWS
description: First Nations leaders and supporters are calling for a national treaty plan. More than 350 people wrote an open letter calling on the Albanese government to provide sufficient support and funding for a treaty process led by First Nations people. Victoria is the only state with an official treaty, but the state's opposition party has promised to cancel it if it wins the election later this year. title: Minister insists 'no choice' on passports for so-called ISIS Brides stuck in Syria | ABC NEWS
description: 00:00 Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke insists the federal government has had no choice but to issue passports to a group of Australians with links to Islamic State and who've tried to begin their journey home.  The federal opposition is demanding the entire group of 34 be blocked from travelling to Australia.  02:10 Middle East Correspondent Matthew Doran explains why the group has waited until now to potentially return to Australia, including the future of the camp they're staying in. title: Alice Springs prepares for possible flooding amid severe weather warning | ABC NEWS
description: Residents in Alice Springs and across central Australia are making preparations for severe weather forecast for the region.  A tropical low is predicted to bring heavy to locally intense rainfall and possible damaging winds over both the central and southeast regions of the NT, with the Barkly already recording high rainfall. Elsie Lange reports for ABC News Northern Territory.
